awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Deep Roots: Wide-Spread Implementation of Community-Driven Evidence-Based Pedagogy
awd_abstract_narration:
This multi-university institutional transformation project, led by the University of Kansas, will both implement and study a model to improve STEM education within seven universities. The ultimate goal is to propagate widespread adoption of evidence-based instructional methods in order to improve undergraduate STEM learning and educational outcomes for both STEM and non-STEM students. Five American institutions funded by this grant, as well as two unfunded Canadian institutions, will test local adaptations of the model on their own campuses. The model is derived from research on institutional change and quality improvement, and builds on an extensive successful initiative (known as the Science Education Initiative, SEI) at two of the partner institutions the University of Colorado at Boulder and the University of British Columbia. The core approach is to support "embedded expertise" in STEM departments to catalyze course transformation and build intellectual communities within and across institutions, in order to share in the development of course reform.  The other participating institutions are the University of Texas at San Antonio, Indiana University, the University of California, Davis, and Queens University in Canada.  

The model of transformation involves embedding STEM education experts (specially prepared postdoctoral scholars or faculty leaders) in departments. These experts will collaborate with department faculty to guide and support the implementation of research-based educational practices in STEM courses. This extension of the SEI model supports change with a smaller infusion of resources by developing communities of scholars around course transformation across departments and institutions. These communities broaden the impact of the embedded experts by expanding support and opportunities for reflective practice for faculty, contributing to the development of a shared vision, and encouraging a critical mass of faculty engagement within departments needed to produce meaningful changes in the teaching environment. Seven research universities that have been actively collaborating through the Bay View Alliance will each implement and evaluate variations of this model on their own campuses. The network serves two functions: 1) to build a community for intellectual exchange and collaboration on evidence-based teaching as a key component of the intervention itself, and 2) to permit a test of whether the intervention model can be localized to different institutional contexts to yield widespread STEM reform.  A combination of quantitative and case study evaluation methods are planned to identify the various dimensions and conditions that signal initial readiness, successful approaches, and sustainable outcomes in participating institutions.

por.por_cntn:
The TRESTLE project implemented and evaluated a model to promote widespread improvement of undergraduate STEM education at six research universities. TRESTLE aimed to catalyze change in teaching practices and culture at the department level, recognizing that the department is a primary unit for academic organization in the research university context. It built on a successful initiative at one of the institutions in which STEM pedagogy experts (i.e., postdoctoral scholars) were embedded in departments to collaborate with faculty on evidence-based course transformation. This seventh institution served as a mentor and comparative institution in the project.  TRESTLE’s adaptation supported change with significantly fewer resources (including fewer experts in a given department), along with varied forms of pedagogical expertise (e.g., postdocs, STEM faculty leaders, education faculty members). To amplify the effects of the embedded experts, TRESTLE added an emphasis on building intellectual community around the work, including the formation of a cross-institutional network, and on making transformed teaching and its impact on students visible within the communities. 

The participating institutions, which were brought together by a coalition called the Bay View Alliance, worked as a Networked Improvement Community (NIC); each campus undertook a similar intervention, with adaptations to their local context. Campus project leaders regularly shared experiences and results to build on each other’s successes and failures and improve the intervention over time, while also yielding new insights into how universities can foster cultures that support better STEM teaching and learning. The initiative’s impact was assessed through a combination of project tracking data, classroom observations, faculty surveys of teaching practices and attitudes, and qualitative departmental case studies. An external evaluation team also studied the project’s implementation and impact on the campuses. Observed outcomes include changes in the teaching and learning environment, tools and resources to support the STEM improvement community, and greater understanding of institutional change. 

 Changes in the Teaching and Learning Environment

 This project fostered a significant spread of course transformation activity across the TRESTLE campuses, with increased numbers of faculty,  departments and courses involved each year. In total, 185 faculty members from 32 departments transformed 173 courses. This activity increased the amount of class time faculty devoted to active and collaborative learning, classroom-based assessment and other student-centered techniques, and resulted in improved learning and successful course completion in courses that affect tens of thousands of students. The course transformation efforts, moreover, continued beyond the period of intervention funding, with former embedded experts and TRESTLE-engaged faculty members continuing to develop teaching innovations to improve student learning. These changes in teaching practice were accompanied by the development of new departmental or institutional structures and processes that support lasting improvements in teaching and learning (e.g., regular teaching forums, new faculty and staff roles to institutionalize teaching innovation), a new population of educational leaders and innovators who are continuing to lead and support transformative work on their campuses and nationally, and sustained department and cross-department communities that value teaching and student learning. These changes to the teaching and learning environment have created a foundation for multiple new educational improvement efforts on the TRESTLE campuses that build directly on the project's work and lessons learned. 

New Resources and Tools

 The TRESTLE project has also resulted in new resources and tools to support the STEM education improvement community, such as: free online COPUS (Smith et al., 2013) observation training sessions and extensive COPUS training resources that have been used by multiple other initiatives, including other NSF-funded STEM education projects;  physics inquiry lab materials; curricular alignment resources; a website and white paper to broaden the use of course-based undergraduate research experiences; and a curated set of resources on teaching large classes. 

New Insights about Institutional Change

The project findings have also furthered our understanding of how to create scalable change in undergraduate STEM education, and the ways in which change strategies are sensitive to local institutional context. Our results provide convergent evidence that TRESTLE’s lower cost adaptation of the embedded-expert model is effective in promoting widespread faculty adoption of evidence-based, inclusive teaching practices and improved student success. Cross-cutting approaches include course redesign as a lever for change in faculty practice; practical and pedagogical support for faculty through embedded expertise; a department-level change focus; multi-level community building for the spread of ideas, shared vision and norms; and making faculty work on course transformation and improved student learning visible. Variation in the spread and sustainability of evidence-based practices across campuses and departments provided insight into how these approaches interact with local contextual factors, including department and faculty readiness and familiarity with student-centered approaches, the breadth and depth of faculty engagement within and across departments, availability of structures and communities to support ongoing reflection and improvement, and support from leadership (e.g., incentives, workload adjustments).
